question_metadata.question_text: What restrictions or incompatibilities are mentioned in the article about the software business model?

responses_by_article.article_title: A Pricing Framework for Software-as-a-Service
responses_by_article.question_text: What restrictions or incompatibilities are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Perpetual licensing no longer applicable → cannot charge upfront perpetual usage license fees
Maintenance revenue eliminated → maintenance is now vendor responsibility, not separate revenue stream
Low switching costs for clients → easy for clients to switch vendors, creating retention pressure
Single-version requirement → cannot maintain multiple software versions for different clients
Compact pricing strategies may limit niche market profitability → difficult to cover broader markets with few pricing components
Complex pricing increases overhead costs → extra costs for customer care support with multiple pricing components
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 2: 'Revenue sources for SaaS are different from those of on-premise software in that the 'perpetual' usage license fee is no longer applicable and clients are charged for only what they have utilized, usually on a periodic basis. Additionally, maintenance revenues disappear as well because maintenance activities are now primarily the responsibilities of SaaS vendors' | Page 2: 'given the nature of SaaS as remotely hosted software services, switching is neither expensive nor tedious for clients' | Page 1: 'SaaS is single versioned, meaning that there is only one version of software being accessed by every client at any moment in time' | Page 5: 'compact pricing strategies may jeopardize SaaS vendor' profits from clients from niche market because it is often difficult to cover a broader markets' | Page 6: 'adopting more components in software pricing will result in complicated pricing solutions, which are often translated to high overheads at the vendors' side, such as extra cost for customer care support'

responses_by_article.article_title: Selection of the Proper Revenue and Pricing Model for SaaS
responses_by_article.question_text: What restrictions or incompatibilities are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Data security concerns → Some customers unwilling to use public cloud → Requires offering traditional licensing for internal data centers
Customer IT infrastructure investment → Organizations with existing IT personnel prefer traditional licensing → Limits pure SaaS adoption
IT policies restricting external installations → Some customers cannot install software outside internal data center → Must offer on-premises option
Lack of network connectivity → Prevents SaaS usage in certain scenarios (e.g., building new telecom networks) → Requires traditional licensing alternative
Customer readiness for new technologies → Low readiness limits SaaS adoption → Necessitates parallel licensing model
Network operator control → In B2B2C scenarios, network operators determine revenue model used → Limits provider's pricing flexibility
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 3: 'However, not all customers are willing to rent the software through the public cloud, due to security concerns or a low readiness for new technologies. For these customers, Firm A makes available a traditional licensing model' | Page 4: 'some customers had an IT policy that did not allow installation of any software outside their own internal data center' | Page 3: 'Another reason to sell a traditional license for internal use was a lack of network connections, in certain cases where a customer was in the process of building a new telecom network' | Page 5: 'customers who had already invested in IT infrastructure and their own IT personnel, they saw traditional software licensing as a more attractive choice' | Page 3-4: 'network operators have become accustomed to using rental models and that is why we have to use one too'

responses_by_article.article_title: Transition to the Cloud: A Vendor Perspective
responses_by_article.question_text: What restrictions or incompatibilities are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Traditional KPIs based on on-premise sales → Conflicts with cloud transition strategy, reduces motivation for change
Disintermediation nature of SaaS → Threatens traditional VAR business model where partners handle installation and logistics
Decreased switching costs in subscription model → Makes it harder to retain customers compared to perpetual license model
R&D resource allocation conflicts → Initial 80/20 split toward SaaS caused quality drop in on-premise products, creating customer concerns
Geographic/regulatory variations → SaaS products developed in one region require significant adaptation for other markets
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 6, Section 5.2.1: 'the KPIs (key performance indicator) at the same were based on the sales of on-premise products, and rendered as a conflict to the transition to cloud.' | Page 6, Section 5.2.1: 'a key question that has risen in every partner's mind is "...given there is nothing to resell, nothing to technically install and no opportunity to provide any kind of logistics, what can a successful SaaS partner contribute?"' | Page 2, Section 2: 'Financially, this renders as a challenge, as such delivery model is considered to have significantly decreased switching costs for customers.' | Page 6, Section 5.2.1: 'due to the decrease in R&D allocation for on-premise software, the quality of the product became a problem subsequently.'

responses_by_article.article_title: Managing a Software Business
responses_by_article.question_text: What restrictions or incompatibilities are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Features vs. quality attributes → Piling features generally reduces software's other qualities (usability, security, maintainability, reliability, efficiency)
Security vs. usability → Increasing security reduces usability
Efficiency vs. maintainability and reliability → Increasing efficiency reduces maintainability and reliability
Stability vs. evolution → Users distrust stale products but enterprises value stability
Transition revenue streams → Existing revenue streams might dry up before new ones start bringing in cash during business model transitions
Open source advantage limitation → Using open source components to minimize licensing costs provides no competitive advantage as competition can do the same
Software construction outsourcing → Questions what value company offers if construction is outsourced
Mobile app market entry → More than two-thirds of millions of mobile phone apps are never or hardly ever downloaded
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 2: 'Many other things determine your offering's quality: its usability, security, maintainability, reliability, and efficiency. All these elements are at odds with each other, and all drive up costs. Piling features generally reduces the software's other qualities. Also, increasing security reduces usability, increasing efficiency reduces maintainability and reliability—the list goes on.' | Page 3: 'Users often distrust a stale product, whereas enterprises typically value stability (until they ditch you for the new kid on the block).' | Page 1: 'Existing revenue streams might dry up before new ones start bringing in cash' | Page 2: 'You might be able to minimize licensing costs by using or modifying open source components, but so can your competition.' | Page 2: 'Software construction might appear easy to outsource, but then what value are you offering?' | Page 1: 'more than two-thirds of the millions of mobile phone apps are never or hardly ever downloaded.'

responses_by_article.article_title: Digital sustainable business models: Using digital technology to integrate ecological sustainability into the core of business models
responses_by_article.question_text: What restrictions or incompatibilities are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Equity dimension excluded from research scope → Incomplete perspective on triple bottom line sustainability (ecological, economic, social)
Geographic limitation to Europe → Limits comparability to other regions with different funding and governmental support
Age restriction (4-10 years) → May miss newer BM designs based on AI, blockchain, Web3
Facilitator-level IT integration excluded → BMs using IT only for efficiency enhancement not included
E-commerce-only excluded → Little differential value from basic online stores
Perfect sustainability unachievable → None of sampled BMs is 100% sustainable in all aspects
BM transformation complexity for incumbents → Difficult to change established successful BM compared to start-ups designing from scratch
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 19, Section 5.4: 'The exclusion of eco-equity from our research scope results in an incomplete perspective on sustainability as defined by the triple bottom line (Elkington, 1998)' | Page 7: 'The sample only includes start-ups headquartered in Europe' | Page 19: 'Since we excluded start-ups founded in the last 4 years, our sample could also be missing newer BM designs, such as those based on AI, blockchain, and Web3' | Page 8: 'We excluded start-ups that only facilitate and support the use of IT because digital technologies are not an essential part of their BM. In addition, IT-mediating BMs that only implement IT in their customer channel for e-Commerce activities such as online stores or online configurators were excluded' | Page 19: 'none of the sampled BMs is perfectly sustainable in all aspects of value creation'

responses_by_article.article_title: When does a freemium business model lead to high performance? — A qualitative comparative analysis based on fuzzy Sets
responses_by_article.question_text: What restrictions or incompatibilities are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Privacy concerns → Consumers perceive digital-intelligent technologies make privacy riskier and doubt privacy security of free products → Detrimental to performance
Bundled model difficulty → Difficult for company to separate high-quality functions and sell them separately (characteristic of bundled model)
Fragmented model complexity → Free products are complex and require modular purchase capability; purchased products are depleted after use
Resource requirements → Bundled models require providing new combinations of products/services and novel incentives which is challenging under high environmental uncertainty
Conversion challenge → Only small percentage of freemium users spend money on premium upgrades
User base size requirement → Must attract disproportionately large user base compared to paid products
Environmental uncertainty trade-off → Fragmented models perform better under high uncertainty while bundled models face challenges balancing efficiency and novelty
Lack of dynamic capabilities → Without high sensing, seizing capabilities, even bundled and fragmented models lead to non-high performance
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 2, Section 1: 'research has shown that consumers perceive that digital-intelligent technologies make privacy riskier and doubt the privacy security of free products, which in turn is detrimental to performance' | 'Compared to paid products, freemium products must attract a disproportionately large user base to generate revenue and capture value' | Page 7, Table 3: 'It is difficult for the company to separate high-quality functions and sell them separately' | 'The purchased products offered by the business are depleted after use' | Page 12: 'bundled freemium business models require firms to provide new combinations of products and services, new value propositions, and novel incentives to transaction participants, which makes it challenging for firms to balance efficiency and novelty enhancement under high environmental uncertainty'

responses_by_article.article_title: Strategy and business model evolution at Adobe: Competing in digital media software industry
responses_by_article.question_text: What restrictions or incompatibilities are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Data sovereignty concerns → Geographic limitations
Customer perception of higher costs → Adoption resistance
Internet dependency → Service availability
Feature saturation risk → Product stability
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 7, Challenges faced: 'There were structural impediments to public cloud adoption, such as data sovereignty concerns. This includes the legal mandate restricting cloud storage outside the user's home country.' | Page 1, Introduction: 'First, customers perceived the new business model as costlier than the previous one.' | Page 6, Key activities: 'The risks of feature saturation and instability in the installed base were harmful byproducts of constantly changing software.'

responses_by_article.article_title: Navigating the paradox of global scaling
responses_by_article.question_text: What restrictions or incompatibilities are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Localization requirements → Impact replicability of global business model and slow down growth
Organizational formalization → Threatens entrepreneurship if decision-making autonomy is compromised
Firm size and standardization → Inhibit pursuit of new opportunities as company grows
Local modifications to business model → Can lead to cascading modifications that unravel business model logic
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 9: 'Overall, there was consensus across informants on the need to minimize local adaptation to maintain the replicability of the global business model' | Page 6: 'As you grow, you need more structure, you need more control, and that will hamper entrepreneurship' | Page 5: 'Local modifications to the business model can lead to cascading modifications, which can unravel the logic of the business model'

responses_by_article.question_text: What restrictions or incompatibilities are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Low app quality → Reduced sampling effectiveness
High app quality → Direct purchase without sampling
Ad-supported free version → Reduced upgrade motivation

Poor quality balance → Users may stop paying or refrain from purchasing

Low service quality → May discourage users from continuing to use the product

responses_by_article.article_title: Current practices and emerging trends of transit apps for fixed-route bus services in the US
responses_by_article.question_text: What restrictions or incompatibilities are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Limited customization in shared apps → Reduced agency branding and control
Data quality issues → Inaccurate information and poor user experience
Vendor dependency → Reduced flexibility and potential delays
Resource constraints → Limited ability to develop in-house solutions
Equity issues → Digital divide affecting some passenger groups
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 4: 'Private sector shared apps were developed by a single vendor but serve multiple transit agencies in different regions/countries. The upfront and operational costs would be minimal as these apps involve limited features and little to no branding' | Page 5: 'Inaccurate trip planning and real-time vehicle information based on the poor quality of General Transit Feed Specification (GTFS)/GTFS-RT feed often mislead passengers'

responses_by_article.article_title: Stuck Inside a Cloud: Do SaaS business models require a rethink of the traditional approach to public market valuation?
responses_by_article.question_text: What restrictions or incompatibilities are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Traditional valuation models → Inadequate for SaaS companies
Market maturity → Limited growth potential in mature markets
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 1: 'SaaS business models are sufficiently different to require bespoke models for valuation' | Page 8: 'When companies have existed for decades and market share is saturated, it is considerably more difficult to grow rapidly'

responses_by_article.article_title: Managing Software-as-a-Service: Pricing and operations
responses_by_article.question_text: What restrictions or incompatibilities are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Multitenancy architecture → Limited user control on the application and security/privacy concerns
Lack-of-fit or unfit disutility → SaaS is not customized for heterogeneous clients unlike OTS software
Capacity constraints → Service quality degradation and customer utility impairment
Security enhancements → Performance penalty and increased processing time
Compliance challenges → Per-user pricing enforcement difficulties
Integration requirements → Customer business processes and IT systems compatibility issues
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 1-2, lines 77-79: 'multitenancy—security and privacy concerns, ease of deployment and updates, limited user control on the application, and the possible outsourcing of infrastructure' | Page 4, lines 267-271: 'incumbents remain providers of off-the-shelf (OTS) software that is often customized for heterogeneous clients, whereas SaaS is not, meaning that an unfit disutility is attributed to SaaS' | Page 9, lines 928-933: 'When capacity addition is not instantaneous, demand (q) may overwhelm capacity and thus impair customer utility' | Page 14, lines 1333-1340: 'many security enhancements (extra verification steps, etc.) are a hassle for customers and incur additional computing tasks (network communication, encryption/decryption, etc.) that slow down the processing of customer requests. For example, AES 256-bit encryption consumes approximately 40% more in computing resources than AES 128-bit encryption does' | Page 8, lines 768-770: 'SaaS services must often integrate the customers' business processes and information technology (IT) systems, so many problems may appear and bring lack-of-fit costs'

responses_by_article.article_title: Toward Building Specialized Information Systems as Software Platforms
responses_by_article.question_text: What restrictions or incompatibilities are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Traditional SIS not extensible from outside → Forces building non-extensible systems
Locking application interface contracts to specific consumer → Limits platform flexibility
Expensive integration platforms → Requires specialized skills to implement and maintain
Need to understand entire codebase → Makes modification and extension difficult
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 2: 'An example of a traditional approach of building a KMS described by S. A. Hakim forces you to build a system that is not extensible from the outside by locking the application interface contracts to a specific consumer' | Page 1: 'A common solution is to buy an expensive integration platform that connects the specialized software systems, thereby allowing them to share information. This solution can work well if the platform is compatible with the underlying software applications and is configured correctly. However, it is an expensive solution that requires specialized skills to implement and maintain' | Page 3: 'The final result should be an SIS that is easy to modify and extend without having to understand the entire codebase'

responses_by_article.article_title: Making a Business Out of (Predictive Application Management in) the Fog
responses_by_article.question_text: What restrictions or incompatibilities are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Large established Infrastructure Providers could copy and overwhelm new entrants → threatens independent business viability

Account limitations for free tier (bounded predictions, lower quality, no support) → affects service accessibility

If network effect is weak → Firm needs more free content, reducing profit
Fixed cost C to divide product → Additional cost burden
Marginal cost existence → Worsens benefit for firm and customers

Dual licensing risk losing community support → perceived as commercial proprietary company
Active/visible company control demotivates contributors → requires invisible governance
Free customers in freemium must be covered by business model → financial sustainability challenge
Contributors derive no direct monetary benefit → exploitation of unpaid labor

responses_by_article.article_title: Difficult Business Models of Digital Business Platforms for Health Data: A Framework for Evaluation of the Ecosystem Viability
responses_by_article.question_text: What restrictions or incompatibilities are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Subscription per user fee → Limited revenue expansion when user base reaches full potential
Public sector budget constraints → Cannot increase monthly fees even when needed for improvements
Misalignment of goals (private provider vs public users) → Deadlock in platform improvement incentives
Regional boundaries → Little need to exchange data between regions, limiting market expansion
Usage-based pricing rejected → Would discourage data consumption, making expensive patients even more costly
Production-based pricing rejected → Only 10% of patient data accessed, unfair to charge for all data created

However, also this option was rejected. Only about 10% of patients visiting primary care would ever have their data accessed using RHIS so why would primary care have to pay for creating data for all their patients?' | Page 6: 'because the usage fee was a monthly fee per user and the potential to expand the user base was already limited the investment would not have resulted into increased revenues. User sensitivity to paid services → Expectation of free digital services → Difficult to charge users directly

Decreased switching costs for customers → makes customer retention more difficult

Long time to market → original idea 'over ten years ahead of its time'

responses_by_article.article_title: Designing business models for cloud platforms
responses_by_article.question_text: What restrictions or incompatibilities are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Trade-off between number of customer sides and complexity → more sides create larger network effects but increase complexity and conflicts of interest. Complementor exclusivity vs comprehensive platform → exclusive rights incentivize partners but limit platform comprehensiveness. Pricing structure conflicts → subsidy on one side requires revenue from other side. Short-term profitability vs long-term ecosystem development → maximizing immediate profits discourages complementor participation. Internal conflicts of interest → existing business units may compete with or undermine platform model. Customer ownership tension → direct end-customer relationships may conflict with developer partner interests. Platform services vs complementary components boundary → unclear demarcation creates competition between provider and complementors.

responses_by_article.article_title: Business Models for Cloud Computing: Experiences from Developing Modeling & Simulation as a Service Applications in Industry
responses_by_article.question_text: What restrictions or incompatibilities are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Complex stakeholder relationships → requires multiple contracts and revenue distribution mechanisms. End-user technical knowledge variations → need different access methods for different user levels. Market heterogeneity → some sectors cannot support pay-per-use models. Platform complexity → end-users should not need to understand different cloud infrastructure providers and charging mechanisms. Revenue distribution complexity → multiple stakeholders require fair compensation mechanisms. Customer support complexity → different support levels needed for different stakeholder interactions. Business model flexibility requirements → one business model insufficient for all use cases. Commercial relationship complexity → simulation vendor would need at least five different contracts with stakeholders.
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 5: 'The multi-stakeholder nature of the CSSP offering adds complexity to the development of the business model as the platform needs to deliver business benefits to all participating stakeholders' | Page 5: 'End-user consumers have different levels of technical knowledge and therefore need access to MSaaS in different ways' | Page 5: 'some sectors cannot support pay-per-use models for example' | Page 8: 'Many of the MSaaS solutions that have been developed place the decision at the software vendor level and hide these details from the end-user (to simplify cloud use and maximize benefit)' | Page 8: 'A simulation software vendor would have to establish commercial relationships between all stakeholders that reflected their contribution to the specific MSaaS product offering. In some cases, this would have involved at least five different contracts with one software vendor'
